title: Curtis Jones puts seal on 10-goal thriller as Liverpool's comeback kids defy Arsenal
text:
Get the biggest Liverpool FC stories by email Subscribe Thank you for subscribing We have more newsletters Show me See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email

How fitting that rising young star Curtis Jones should decide an epic, outrageous Carabao Cup tie, given the way Liverpool’s kids inscribed their very own chapter in Anfield history.

Not all of them will make it here at Anfield, perhaps some won’t reach a high like this again.

But as their manager Jurgen Klopp said afterwards, they will have this outrageous, impossible night for the rest of their lives.

Where to start on a crazy evening that almost defies description?

Perhaps with the fact that the score after 90 minutes of a wonderfully naive contest with Arsenal was 5-5…greater than the result in the shoot-out that followed!

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

Jones an 18 year old from Toxteth, showed nerveless courage to convert fifth penalty to put his side into the quarter final.

Before that, young keeper Caoimhin Kelleher had saved Arsenal’s fourth spot kick, from former Real Madrid man Dani Ceballos.

And even before that, 16 year-old Harvey Elliott won a penalty to drag his side back into the game, then Neco Williams, 18, saved the tie for the Reds with a brilliant assist for Divock Origi deep into stoppage time.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

There were so many heroes it is hard to stop naming them, and Arsenal had several too, their frighteningly talented teenage striker Gabriel Martinelli scoring twice, and Joe Willock, who seems positively ancient at 20, produced a worldie which had looked destined to decide the game.

He didn’t, because even Liverpool’s boys never know when they are beaten.

Klopp described them as special, and it’s not hard to see why he rates them so highly.

(Image: Robbie Stephenson/JMP/REX)

Even by half time, there were echoes of that crazy Andrey Arshavin 4-4 game between those two sides back in April 2009,

Yet that scoreline was reached just past the hour mark, and Anfield was left wondering if they should look instead for comparisons with the rugby World Cup taking place out in Japan.

The tone for the most breathless of cup ties within six frenetic minutes as Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain saw his cross comically turned into his own net by Shkodran Mustafi.

But there it was Arsenal’s turn. They capitalised on some good fortune when Lucas Torreira was clearly offside as he converted a rebound from the hugely impressive Mesut Ozil’s shot.

But that sparked an onslaught, with the exciting Gabriel Martinelli scoring twice in quick succession, putting another rebound in before he turned in a fine cross from young prospect Bukayo Saka.

(Image: Getty Images)

All three goals came from mistakes - surprisingly from senior players like Oxlade-Chamberlain and Origi, but Elliott atoned for one of his just before the interval when he darted into the box and went down - rather theatrically - as Martinelli touched his foot. Milner made no mistake from the spot.

There was to be no let up. Arsenal scored again minutes after the break, when Milner, the oldest man on the pitch, gave the ball away in his own box, and Maitland-Niles found the net after a brilliantly aware Ozil back heel.

(Image: Action Images via Reuters)

But Oxlade-Chamberlain atoned for his earlier error with an incredible strike against his former club on 57 minutes, and then Origi followed suit in making good, this time with an audacious turn on the edge of the box.

62 minutes, the score 4-4 and the Kop chanting we want more. They got it.

Willock ran from half way to seemingly win it, but then came the grandstand finish, a cross from Williams and outstanding athleticism on the half turn from Origi.

A timeless goal in a timeless classic.
description: LIVERPOOL 5-5 ARSENAL (5-4 pens): One of Anfield's own landed the final blow in an outrageous Carabao Cup clash
